title: stlitepack
text:
stlitepack is a Python utility that helps you turn your existing Streamlit apps into stlite apps ‚Äî lightweight, browser-only Streamlit apps that run entirely in the client without a server.
With stlitepack, you can:

üì¶ Pack your Streamlit app into a stlite-ready format (current functionality).
üöÄ (Upcoming) Generate GitHub Actions workflows to auto-deploy your app to GitHub Pages.
üóÇÔ∏è (Planned) Add support for multi-page apps, external resources, and more.



pip install stlitepack



from stlitepack import pack

# Pack your Streamlit app (e.g., "app.py") into a stlite bundle
pack("app.py", output_dir="docs")
This will create a docs/ folder containing your stlite-ready app files, which you can serve as static files.




v0.1: Single-page app packing
v0.2: Helper functions for GitHub Pages auto-deploy (via GitHub Actions workflow generation)
v0.3: Multi-page app support (for pages/ subfolder method)
v0.4: Resource bundling (images, CSVs, assets, etc.)
v0.5: Multi-page app support (for st.navigation() method)
v0.6: Auto-handling of stlite-specific features (e.g.¬†asyncio vs sleep)
v0.7: TOML or YAML file support as optional alternative to the packing function
v1.0: Full toolkit for packaging, deploying, and managing stlite apps




Contributions, feature requests, and feedback are welcome! Open an issue or submit a pull request to help improve stlitepack.

This package was developed with the assistance of ChatGPT (OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-5 model) as a coding and documentation partner. All code and design decisions were reviewed and finalized by a human, and ChatGPT‚Äôs output was used as a foundation rather than a final product.

title: pack.pack
text:
pack.pack(
    app_file,
    extra_files=None,
    requirements=None,
    title='App',
    output_dir='docs',
    output_file='index.html',
    stylesheet_version='0.84.1',
    js_bundle_version='0.84.1',
    use_raw_api=False,
)
Pack a Streamlit app into a stlite-compatible index.html file.
This function reads a Streamlit Python script, injects it into an HTML template compatible with stlite, and writes the output as index.html. The resulting HTML can be served as static content (e.g., via GitHub Pages).
If additional pages are found in a ‚Äòpages‚Äô folder at the same level as the main app file, these will be added in as additional files.











Name
Type
Description
Default




app_file
str
Path to the main Streamlit application file (entrypoint) (e.g., "app.py").
required


extra_files
list[str]
Additional files to mount into the app (e.g.¬†.streamlit/config.toml).
None


requirements
str or list of str
Either: - Path to a requirements.txt file (str), or - A list of required Python packages (list of str).
None


title
str
Title to insert into the HTML <title> tag. Default is "stlite app".
'App'


output_dir
str
Directory where the generated index.html will be written. Default is "dist".
'docs'


use_raw_api
bool
If True, will use the version of the template that calls the mount() API explicitly. Multi-page apps are not currently supported with the raw API, so set this to False if you wish to create a multi-page app. Default is False.
False














Name
Type
Description





FileNotFoundError
If the specified app_file does not exist.



ValueError
If requirements is not a list or a valid requirements file path.







Currently supports only single-page Streamlit apps.
Future versions will support multi-page apps, additional resources, and GitHub Pages deployment automation.




Pack an app using a requirements file:
>>> from stlitepack import pack
>>> pack("app.py", requirements="requirements.txt", title="My App")
Pack an app with inline requirements:
>>> pack("app.py", requirements=["pandas", "numpy"], title="Data Explorer")
The resulting HTML file will be written to dist/index.html by default.
